message_1: A physics student wants to measure the radiation exposure of a sample. They have a Geiger-Muller (GM) tube, oscilloscope, and a radioactive sample of unknown activity. Describe an experimental procedure that can be used to determine the activity of the radioactive sample by using the GM tube and oscilloscope.
message_2:
To determine the activity of the radioactive sample using the Geiger-Muller (GM) tube and oscilloscope, follow this experimental procedure:

1. Set up the equipment: Place the GM tube on a stable surface, and connect it to the oscilloscope using appropriate cables. Ensure that the oscilloscope is properly calibrated and set to display voltage pulses generated by the GM tube.

2. Position the radioactive sample: Place the radioactive sample at a fixed distance from the GM tube, ensuring that the distance is large enough to avoid any saturation effects in the GM tube. It is also important to minimize any background radiation by performing the experiment in a low-radiation environment or by shielding the setup with appropriate materials.

3. Measure background radiation: Before introducing the radioactive sample, record the background radiation by counting the number of pulses detected by the GM tube over a fixed period (e.g., 5 minutes). This will help account for any background radiation present in the environment.

4. Measure sample radiation: Introduce the radioactive sample and start counting the number of pulses detected by the GM tube over the same fixed period as in step 3. Repeat this measurement several times to obtain an average count rate.

5. Subtract background radiation: Subtract the average background count rate from the average sample count rate to obtain the net count rate due to the radioactive sample.

6. Calculate activity: To determine the activity of the radioactive sample, divide the net count rate by the efficiency of the GM tube. The efficiency of the GM tube is the probability that a radioactive decay event will be detected by the tube, and it depends on factors such as the type of radiation emitted by the sample and the geometry of the setup. Efficiency values can be found in the literature or provided by the manufacturer of the GM tube.

7. Analyze the results: The calculated activity represents the number of radioactive decay events per unit time (usually expressed in Becquerels or Curies). Compare this value to known activities of different radioactive isotopes to identify the isotope present in the sample or to assess the level of radiation exposure.

By following this experimental procedure, the physics student can determine the activity of the radioactive sample using the Geiger-Muller tube and oscilloscope.
